results.title: Fabrics of the future
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “This Modern Age”.
Deals with the development of synthetic fibres, and the challenge which the textile industry based on the use of these fibres offers to the woollen and cotton industries.

results.title: Education for living
results.brief_description:
Episode number 27 of Series “This Modern Age”.
The main changes and developments in education in Britain are reviewed, with flash-backs to the “bad old days”. The film shows what is being done to provide more and better schools and to train the teachers to service them.

results.title: Antarctic whalehunt
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
Part of the series “This Modern Age”, this film deals with modern methods of hunting and killing whales, the case for more humane methods, and the possible effects of indiscriminate depletion of the number of whales in the Antarctic.
results.description:

results.title: Paddleboats of the Murray River
results.creator_credit: Roy Mason, John Mabey, Rhonda Mabey and Sorena Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Ted Egan’s story of the Paddlewheelers of the mighty Murray River begins at Mannum in South Australia which claims to be the oldest of the riverboat towns. Ted travels on almost all the paddlewheelers beginning with “The Adelaide”. At Mildura a special race is staged for the new and old paddleboats featuring “The Melbourne”, “The Rothbury”, “The Avoca”, “The Coonawarra” and “The Murray River Queen”. At Swan Hill we see “The Gem”, “The Pyap” and a replica of the steam driven “Emmy Lou”. At Echuca Ted travels aboard the “Pevensey”, “The Adelaide” and the “Etona” and an old missionary boat.

results.title: Mysterious Australia: The shaping of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
A journey through the puzzles that nature used as it designed and shaped the Australian continent. The story criss-crosses the continent discovering the world’s oldest living organisms and how sea fossils three hundred million years old came to be on a mountain top hundreds of kilometres from the ocean.

results.title: The Islands of Torres Strait
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Torres Strait is a treacherous waterway between Cape York, the northern most tip of the Australian mainland and Papua New Guinea. The shallow strait is dotted with Islands and coral outcrops. From Possession Island at the southern extremity, Captain James Cook formally laid claim to the Australian colonies in the name of England. Later the Queensland Government moved to control the Islands of the Strait and their people. Once, the islanders currency of trade was human heads, and headhunting raids between the islands and mainland Papua New Guinea was part of life. On this journey through the islands, Ted Egan meets some old friends, sees dugout canoes being built and meets the keeper of the legendary Drums of Mer.

results.title: Broome and the Pearl Coast
results.creator_credit: Martyn Down, John Mabey, Rhonda Mabey, AFFC and Sorena
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Broome, in the remote north-west of Australia is famous for its pearling industry. Travelling the breadth of the Pearl Coast, Ted Egan encounters a number of extraordinary people like Yoshinori Maeda who came to Australia as a young man to fish, but decided to stay. The vast panoramic coast and desert of the north-west is explored, including the beautiful splendour of Deepwater Point, 200kms from Broome.

results.title: Discovering a rainforest
results.creator_credit: Kenyon Castle, John Mabey and Rhonda Mabey
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
The first part of the Australian continent to be touched by the morning sun is the sentinel peak of Mt. Warning, the core of an ancient volcano. In the eroded valleys and rugged mountain ranges that surround the peak are some of the world’s most beautiful rainforests, just a short journey from Surfers Paradise, Australia’s tourist playground. Sandwiched between the ocean and the outer rim of the volcano exists an incredible pot pourri of people and lifestyles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kenyon Castle, John Mabey and Rhonda Mabey
